poem:
Before the beginning

	Or angels and man began,

	And even after the end,

	God, Three in One You have ever been

	Living, giving, sharing within,

	You, the best gift that can be given.
versetext: In the beginning was the Word, and the Word was with God, and the Word was God.

poem:
Spirit of God like a dove

	Above this formless void, the deep, dark,

	boiling turmoil of my heart,

	Above the chaos of my life,

	Brood over me in all wise love.

	Make me Your new creation in Christ.
versetext: The earth was formless and empty. Darkness was on the surface of the deep and God’s Spirit was hovering over the surface of the waters.

poem:
The first written word that God said

	Was “let there be light.”

	When His Word enters us, it gives sight,

	Then our darkness is dead.
versetext: God said, “Let there be light,” and there was light.

poem:
Our hearts were in darkness, and dark was in us

	Until we saw light shining from the face of Jesus.

	Then, for us, it was the first day again

	And we became a new creation.
versetext: seeing it is God who said, “Light will shine out of darkness,” who has shone in our hearts, to give the light of the knowledge of the glory of God in the face of Jesus Christ.

poem:
A day starts at night

	And we too begin in the dark,

	Until His Word enters our heart

	And makes everything bright
versetext: God called the light “day”, and the darkness he called “night”. There was evening and there was morning, the first day.

poem:
God works, dividing and setting apart:

	Daylight from dark,

	Waters parted to become sea and sky,

	From the wet oceans, land that is dry.

	Then vegetation sprang from earth.

	Our Maker is doing the same with the church,

	A new creation which He separates and sanctifies.
versetext: God saw the light, and saw that it was good. God divided the light from the darkness.

poem:
Next, He adorns and multiplies:

	Enhancing the heavens with ruling lights,

	Flooding waters above and below with abundant life.

	Then diverse creatures on land, under man’s dominion.

	And finally, from the man, a wife.

	Our creator is doing the same with His Bride

	Adding grace upon grace until we reign at His side.
versetext: God made the two great lights: the greater light to rule the day, and the lesser light to rule the night. He also made the stars.

poem:
A new year, month and week has begun

	And like His Book, Chapter and Verse One

	Start this year, month and this day

	‘In the beginning’ with God, the same way.
versetext: In the beginning, God created the heavens and the earth.

poem:
Maker and Lord of the entire Universe,

	Observer and Ruler of the minutest thing,

	Master of all spirits above, on and below the earth

	You control the greatest and least of all being.
versetext: ‘For in him we live, and move, and have our being.’ As some of your own poets have said, ‘For we are also his offspring.’

poem:
In Christ you have been created again

	According to God’s eternal plan.

	Ordained before creation began,

	To be a walking work for Him.
versetext: For we are his workmanship, created in Christ Jesus for good works, which God prepared before that we would walk in them.

poem:
Like sleeping seeds, from earth we will suddenly spring and sprout

	As soon as we hear from clouds that secret and select shout sing out.
versetext: having been born again, not of corruptible seed, but of incorruptible, through the word of God, which lives and remains forever.

poem:
The first Adam kept a garden

	The Last was planted in one.

	The first man came up from the ground

	From Second comes down from heaven.
versetext:
So also it is written, “The first man, Adam, became a living soul.”
 The last Adam became a life-giving spirit.

poem:
There have only ever been two men.

	The First was he who came up from earth.

	The Second, the Son of Man, Who came down from heaven.

	Every person ever born is a child of Adam,

	But from the Second are only those who have had New Birth.

	Whose family do you want to be in?
versetext: The first man is of the earth, made of dust. The second man is the Lord from heaven.

poem:
God is good all the time.

	All the time God is good.

	God is good and does good.

	God is great and greatly to be praised.

	His goodness is great

	And His greatness is good.

	He was, is and ever will be.
versetext:
Jesus said to him,
“Why do you call me good? No one is good except one—God.

poem:
Pride of face, race and place,

	Your measure and treasure, cash and cargo,

	Where you’ve been and where you’ll go,

	What you have learned, earned, accomplished and won,

	Without grateful humility it all ends in disgrace and destruction.
versetext:
Pride goes before destruction,
and a haughty spirit before a fall.

poem:
God, You are One and Trinity

	All good, all true,

	In all You are and do,

	The only Divinity.
versetext: Hear, Israel: Yahweh is our God. Yahweh is one.

poem:
Love is not taking but giving.

	It is not possessing but losing for the beloved,

	Dying so the other can go on living,

	Going low to send them above.
versetext: In this is love, not that we loved God, but that he loved us, and sent his Son as the atoning sacrifice for our sins.

poem:
Millennia ago Moses was inspired to write Psalm 90,

	Long before the start of modern medicine and scientific inquiry.

	It states we only have 70 or 80 years until our ‘Date of Expiry.’

	And after so much time we still have the same limited life expectancy.

	But our ‘Use by Date’ is only from sunrise and sunset.

	Count on it!
versetext:
The days of our years are seventy,
or even by reason of strength eighty years;
yet their pride is but labor and sorrow,
for it passes quickly, and we fly away.

poem:
Christ inquired, ‘can’t watch one hour?’

	And we must respond, ‘we can’t,’

	Unless you give us power

	And the help of Your Spirit.
versetext: In the same way, the Spirit also helps our weaknesses, for we don’t know how to pray as we ought. But the Spirit himself makes intercession for us with groanings which can’t be uttered.

poem:
When you go to a new venue

	Where no one knows you

	And you have no reputation,

	You can give in to the anointing

	And pray and sing in the Spirit

	With freedom and abandon

	Not caring who hears it.

	So tonight, instead of a new location

	Shout out, and get a transformation.
versetext: When they had prayed, the place was shaken where they were gathered together. They were all filled with the Holy Spirit, and they spoke the word of God with boldness.

poem:
On the flotsam and jetsam of death and destruction

	The pure and peaceful dove could find no place to alight and stay

	Until the Lamb of God, rising from His Water Baptism

	Became the resting place from which she would never fly away.
versetext: but the dove found no place to rest her foot, and she returned into the ship to him, for the waters were on the surface of the whole earth. He put out his hand, and took her, and brought her to him into the ship.

poem:
There is a yard where all is quiet and in order.

	Neighbors don’t dispute over property or borders,

	Family fights and feuds have all ceased,

	Even politicians sleep together in peace.

	Don’t wait until you are in the cemetery

	To live together in tranquility and harmony.
versetext:
Let me not be disappointed, Yahweh, for I have called on you.
Let the wicked be disappointed.
Let them be silent in Sheol.

poem:
Good Shepherd of men

	Give us Your grace and direction,

	Provision and protection.

	Show us how go out and come in,

	To enter rest in Your heavenly habitation.
versetext:
Yahweh is my shepherd:
I shall lack nothing.

poem:
Like with Levi there will come an occasion

	When you will have to make a painful decision.

	With a sword in hand you will have to take a stand.

	Whose side will it be on, God or man?
versetext:
then Moses stood in the gate of the camp, and said, “Whoever is on Yahweh’s side, come to me!”
All the sons of Levi gathered themselves together to him.

poem:
A king cried out “who is on my side?”

	Who can resist that ageless spirit of seduction,

	In the perfumed and painted Jezebel exemplified?

	Only eunuchs could reject and eject that wicked woman.
versetext:
He lifted up his face to the window, and said, “Who is on my side? Who?”
Two or three eunuchs looked out at him.

poem:
Made in Your image and likeness

	Body, Soul and Spirit our essence.

	Like You, three in one, a trinity,

	Because You are the best way to be.
versetext: God said, “Let us make man in our image, after our likeness: and let them have dominion over the fish of the sea, and over the birds of the sky, and over the livestock, and over all the earth, and over every creeping thing that creeps on the earth.”

poem:
Created to be creative like Him.

	Given authority and dominion,

	We were made to multiply.

	Yet many don’t even try.
versetext: God created man in his own image. In God’s image he created him; male and female he created them.

poem:
Whom we preach, not a what,

	What we teach, not guessed, but got.

	To everyone, not some,

	To be perfect when He comes.
versetext: whom we proclaim, admonishing every man and teaching every man in all wisdom, that we may present every man perfect in Christ Jesus;

poem:
We work out what He has worked in.

	Straining, struggling and striving

	According to His working that always wins

	And always accomplishes what it begins.
versetext: for which I also labor, striving according to his working, which works in me mightily.

poem:
Like motes of dust dancing in a light ray,

	Unseen breath lifting it ever more upward,

	We are looking for that glorious day

	When to our Maker we are raptured.
versetext: For the Lord himself will descend from heaven with a shout, with the voice of the archangel, and with God’s trumpet. The dead in Christ will rise first,

poem:
Ever and all glorious Lord

	Who all creation holds

In Your infinite embrace.

	My heart and soul mold

	And my spirit enfold

	Until this clay displays Your face.
versetext: But we have this treasure in clay vessels, that the exceeding greatness of the power may be of God, and not from ourselves.

poem:
The Blood of Jesus,

	So precious to us!
versetext: but with precious blood, as of a lamb without blemish or spot, the blood of Christ;

poem:
Your polished leather Bible cover may shine

	With edges gilt and ribbons ironed,

	But it is the light inside that shows

	The beauty of God’s written gems and gold.
versetext: not stealing, but showing all good fidelity; that they may adorn the doctrine of God, our Savior, in all things.

poem:
Let there be a transforming and lasting revelation.

	Revival is not just noise and perspiration,

	But the Spirit making a holy change within.

	How often after singing and dancing ends

	Does the sin begin again?
versetext:
So we will not turn away from you.
Revive us, and we will call on your name.

poem:
Just ones shall live by faith,

	Neither hurried nor in haste,

	Not worried or withdrawn,

	Waiting, while they carry on.
versetext:
But the righteous will live by faith.
If he shrinks back, my soul has no pleasure in him.”

poem:
You must resist sickness

	By His strength and righteousness.

	You must not give in to death.

	God is not finished using you yet.

Being gravely ill is like taking a terrible trip,

	Or voyaging on a tempest-tossed ship.

	It threatens to end in disaster and injury

	But Jesus brings us through to health and victory.
versetext:
But when Jesus heard it, he said,
“This sickness is not to death, but for the glory of God, that God’s Son may be glorified by it.”

poem:
We are hand made by God,

Clean clay, creative sod,

	Up thrust dust, standing soil;

	But by His breath, an eternal soul.
versetext: Yahweh God formed man from the dust of the ground, and breathed into his nostrils the breath of life; and man became a living soul.

poem:
Stop running and soar.

	Wait on God and you can do more.
versetext:
But those who wait for Yahweh will renew their strength.
They will mount up with wings like eagles.
They will run, and not be weary.
They will walk, and not faint.

poem:
We were made in His image and likeness,

	Inspired to be creative like Him.

	But like our breath, the resemblance is within.

	Don’t stay stuck in the muck and clay.

	Rise up from the earth and dust,

	And do something new and unique today.
versetext: God created man in his own image. In God’s image he created him; male and female he created them.

poem:
As in those early days of destiny,

	When you first heard His call

	Which you answered in humility,

	Do you still feel purpose and challenge?

Maybe once more you can forsake all

Take up your cross and follow Him again.
versetext:
Then Jesus said to his disciples,
“If anyone desires to come after me, let him deny himself, and take up his cross, and follow me.

poem:
Did your first love last,

	Or is it in the past?

	It may have been left,

	But it is not lost.

	Find it at the foot of the Cross.
versetext: But I have this against you, that you left your first love.

poem:
Your first works were done when your faith was young.

	You didn’t lead singing or even know the words of a song.

You couldn’t preach, find verses or offer Biblical proof.

	You could only believe, receive and worship in spirit and truth.
versetext: Remember therefore from where you have fallen, and repent and do the first works; or else I am coming to you swiftly, and will move your lamp stand out of its place, unless you repent.

poem:
Binding His donkey’s foal and colt to a vine

	The Lion of Judah washed His garments in wine.

	Though our sins have stained us scarlet

	Washing with Jesus’ blood will remove it.
versetext:
Binding his foal to the vine,
his donkey’s colt to the choice vine;
he has washed his garments in wine,
his robes in the blood of grapes.

poem:
Some wounds we cannot see

	Like a bruise which is blood under skin,

	Or a heart broken deeply within.

	Christ suffered these for you and me.

	He was wounded for our sin

	And bruised for our iniquity.
versetext:
But he was pierced for our transgressions.
He was crushed for our iniquities.
The punishment that brought our peace was on him;
and by his wounds we are healed.

poem:
When you let God be the boss

	Death on a cross is not loss.

	So say like Jesus did, ‘not my will be done’

	Then, even when you lose, you have won.
versetext:
Again, a second time he went away, and prayed, saying,
“My Father, if this cup can’t pass away from me unless I drink it, your desire be done.”

poem:
The tomb is not a door to doom

	But a changing room

	Where we leave these clothes of clay

	To put on our bridal array.
versetext: if so be that being clothed we will not be found naked.

poem:
Some say they cannot fast and pray

	Or watch through a whole night.

	But they won’t know until they try it.

	If you succeed it is through His ability.

	If you fail, then it is God’s responsibility
versetext: You lust, and don’t have. You murder and covet, and can’t obtain. You fight and make war. You don’t have, because you don’t ask.

poem:
Do you love your laptop more than your Bible?

	Has your phone and tablet become a habit?

	Are you dependent on the internet?

	Not all addictions are chemical. Some are digital.

	Better take a break and break the attachments

	Before they connect you to a funeral.
versetext: Don’t love the world or the things that are in the world. If anyone loves the world, the Father’s love isn’t in him.

poem:
Just Salvation,

	Being Born Again,

	And having the lowest place in Heaven,

	Would be enough for us to praise Him without end.
versetext: The saying is faithful and worthy of all acceptance, that Christ Jesus came into the world to save sinners; of whom I am chief.

poem:
It is a mystery

	That when we surrender

	To our strong Defender

	We get the victory.
versetext: Yahweh will fight for you, and you shall be still.”

poem:
Surrender to God is not abrogation of self,

	Or an abolition of our autonomy.

	What we thought was independence

	Was actually bondage to sin and selfishness.

	So submission to Jesus

	Because we do it willingly,

	Makes our liberty precious,

	And our freedom more free.
versetext: Being made free from sin, you became bondservants of righteousness.

poem:
Uncreated Creator of light and life

	Make your Church into the Last Adam’s wife.
versetext: Yahweh God made a woman from the rib which he had taken from the man, and brought her to the man.

poem:
When young, our lusts are stronger than us.

	Your desires have grown but not your experience.

	They can cause you to lose your inheritance.

	So when you feel temptation come

	You better run.

	Put between you and it some distance.
versetext: Flee from youthful lusts; but pursue righteousness, faith, love, and peace with those who call on the Lord out of a pure heart.

poem:
In these modern days

	With everything instantaneous

	Seeking God is extraneous.

	Preachers have modern ways

	To prepare their messages.

	They can dive into a hard drive

	For some leftovers to revive,

	Or rehydrate if freeze dried.

	They find it cold and old on the Internet

	Then reheat or microwave it,

	Even though it had long died.

	How about instead of stealing sermons,

	We wait on God for them?
versetext: I will stand at my watch, and set myself on the ramparts, and will look out to see what he will say to me, and what I will answer concerning my complaint.

poem:
Jesus did it daily and prayed it three times,

	Not my will but Thine.

	So let Him lead moment by moment

	And you won’t be a disappointment.
versetext:
saying,
“Father, if you are willing, remove this cup from me. Nevertheless, not my will, but yours, be done.”

poem:
Whether we build with gold or grass,

	Through the fire it will have to pass.

	The chaff in a flash just turns to smoke and ash

	But the gold only becomes more pure and precious.
versetext: each man’s work will be revealed. For the Day will declare it, because it is revealed in fire; and the fire itself will test what sort of work each man’s work is.

poem:
Proud people seek position and power,

	The humble thirst for holiness and Him

	Who humbled Himself lower and lower

	Until God raised Him to the height of heaven.
versetext: And being found in human form, he humbled himself, becoming obedient to death, yes, the death of the cross.

poem:
“He gives His beloved sleep”

	A verse used when feeling tired and weak.

	But more often when stuck in bed,

	Lazy, slothful and spiritually dead.
versetext:
It is vain for you to rise up early,
to stay up late,
eating the bread of toil;
for he gives sleep to his loved ones.

poem:
Even if it’s too early, get up and about!

	Even if it’s too late, rise, get out!

	Not just an alarm, but all creation rings.

	Not just birds, but stars and angels sing.

	If you don’t do it, the sleeping stones may shout.
versetext:
to proclaim your loving kindness in the morning,
and your faithfulness every night,

poem:
Don’t give your Old Man any mind

	Or it will drag you down to earth over time.

	Love those things above, hidden in Heaven,

	Where Christ enthroned is waiting to reign

	Beside His Bride who overcame in the world below

	And stayed always watching and ready to go.
versetext: Set your mind on the things that are above, not on the things that are on the earth.

poem:
Don’t let this make you afraid

	But the Lord has already seen your grave.

	On every calendar is the date of your last day.

	Don’t despair, the date of the Rapture is also there.

	Your times are in His Hand

	And so is your Resurrection.
versetext:
My times are in your hand.
Deliver me from the hand of my enemies, and from those who persecute me.

poem:
Acting is a terrible profession

	Often it ends in demonic possession.

	Because they make a living out of living a lie,

	Actors often commit suicide or overdose and die.

	Don’t be seduced by society’s standard of fortune and fame,

	Most of those adored acting idols and stars end in shame.
versetext: Now we call the proud happy; yes, those who work wickedness are built up; yes, they tempt God, and escape.’

poem:
Even angels and seraphim cover their faces and feet.

	It is not that all are so dirty, ugly and lowly.

	But that our lovely Lord is so high, and lofty and holy.

	One day the veil and curtain of death will part

	And we see Him with open face and heart.
versetext: He will destroy in this mountain the surface of the covering that covers all peoples, and the veil that is spread over all nations.

poem:
There was a rich poor man, always so sad.

	He was never glad for all the gifts from God he had.

	As he lived, breathed, drank and saw light for free,

	He continually complained of his poverty.

	Let us give thanks to God continually

	For all He bestows upon us so richly.
versetext: Charge those who are rich in this present world that they not be haughty, nor have their hope set on the uncertainty of riches, but on the living God, who richly provides us with everything to enjoy;

poem:
One way you can know that God is true

	Is when He makes something new and good through you.

	You will experience evidence of His presence and grace.

	When you allow Him to inspire and equip you to create.
versetext: But by the grace of God I am what I am. His grace which was given to me was not futile, but I worked more than all of them; yet not I, but the grace of God which was with me.

poem:
On the Holy Highway to Zion

	The lowest and lamest of men,

	Even the wayward fool, will not fail or fall

	Until God has fulfilled His purpose in all.
versetext:
A highway will be there, a road,
and it will be called The Holy Way.
The unclean shall not pass over it,
but it will be for those who walk in the Way.
Wicked fools will not go there.

poem:
When we travail, and make intercession

	We give strength and support to our brethren

	Who are too weary, weak and broken.

	Worn out ourselves and ignorant of their problems

	We send them strength and wisdom to solve them.

	Holy Spirit help us utter prayers that can’t be spoken.
versetext: In the same way, the Spirit also helps our weaknesses, for we don’t know how to pray as we ought. But the Spirit himself makes intercession for us with groanings which can’t be uttered.

poem:
Whatever good works you may do,

	And may there be many of them,

	They will never be enough to make God take you back again,

	That price was fully paid when He gave His Son for your sin.
versetext:
For the redemption of their life is costly,
no payment is ever enough,

poem:
Some appear so weak, harsh and sour

	As they preach about God’s joyous power,

	Teaching of fellowship and love for others

	As they judge, reject and condemn their brothers.
versetext: Walk in wisdom toward those who are outside, redeeming the time.

poem:
Others are so exclusive, selective and hard-shelled

	They make it hard to get in heaven and easy to enter hell.

	Such messengers make lost sinners ask themselves the question

	If the exemplars of Zion and inhabitants of heaven are so

	I am not sure such a paradise is a place I would want to go.
versetext: Let your speech always be with grace, seasoned with salt, that you may know how you ought to answer each one.

poem:
Everything the Devil caused to be cursed

	Jesus redeemed, restored and blest.

	He sweat blood on the cursed earth

	To give us fruitfulness and rest.

	He saw His Seed and travail in our New Birth.
versetext: Christ redeemed us from the curse of the law, having become a curse for us. For it is written, “Cursed is everyone who hangs on a tree,”

poem:
From the cursed ground

	Thorns became a crown.

	Jesus did not take down from a tree as Adam

	Or use them to hide behind and cover up sin

	But was publicly nailed up naked on one.
versetext:
It will yield thorns and thistles to you;
and you will eat the herb of the field.

poem:
The first man hid from the presence of God in a garden,

	But at Calvary the Father hid His face from the Son.

	Jesus willingly took on the lowest and most abased form,

	Being made like unto a slain serpent and crushed worm.

	He did not blame others, but forgave with last His breaths.

	He took our sin in His sinless body, by dying He destroyed death.
versetext: They heard Yahweh God’s voice walking in the garden in the cool of the day, and the man and his wife hid themselves from the presence of Yahweh God among the trees of the garden.

poem:
God so loved, so He gave and gave and gave

	His only Son through a womb, a cross and a grave,

	To descend under the earth and ascend above it too,

	To accomplish what no one else could do.

	To possess the keys of Hell and death,

	So His beloved would not perish, but be forever saved.
versetext: For God so loved the world, that he gave his one and only Son, that whoever believes in him should not perish, but have eternal life.

poem:
The jewels of Jesus

	Adorning His Church and crown

	And that Holy City coming down

	Were first found hidden deep within the dark and dirty ground.

	Though we once were captives, His inheritance and treasure is in us.
versetext: They shall be mine,” says Yahweh of Armies, “my own possession in the day that I make, and I will spare them, as a man spares his own son who serves him.

poem:
Enthroned incandescent within that transparent city

	Our King of kings blazes brilliantly throughout eternity.

	There we will reflect, refract, mirror, magnify and display His glory

	Without spot, stain, fault or flaw for all creation to see.
versetext: having the glory of God. Her light was like a most precious stone, as if it were a jasper stone, clear as crystal;

poem:
If you hear I die, don’t cry.

	Keep your eyes lifted and dry.

	I plan to miss my funeral and fly

	And be laughing and dancing on high.
versetext: But I am in a dilemma between the two, having the desire to depart and be with Christ, which is far better.

poem:
There is poetry in you too

	Tomorrow’s is for you to do.

	So by His grace

	Fill every empty space

	With songs and poems of praise
versetext:
My heart overflows with a noble theme.
I recite my verses for the king.
My tongue is like the pen of a skillful writer.

poem: For God so loved the world that he gave his only begotten son
versetext: For God so loved the world, that he gave his one and only Son, that whoever believes in him should not perish, but have eternal life.

poem:
Whatever the couture

	To the folks in the future

	We are already way out of style.

	Chasing after change is futile.

	No matter how much it cost

	The prize is always and already lost.
versetext: the fine robes, the capes, the cloaks, the purses,

poem:
If you would gaze more and more each day

	Into the glass of God’s Word and stay

	Mindful of the face of Jesus there

	You will be transformed forever
versetext: For if anyone is a hearer of the word and not a doer, he is like a man looking at his natural face in a mirror;

poem:
Pay no attention to the time.

	Look to the Son, not the sun.

	Look to His face, not your watch’s

	Watch His hands, not the clock’s.

	Listen for His call, not the phone’s.

Not just in a dry, desolate desert

	But more in a well-watered garden,

	Where all is comfortable and pleasant,

	Is the place where our hearts are dulled and hardened

	And we forget the One who enriched and blest us.
versetext: Lot lifted up his eyes, and saw all the plain of the Jordan, that it was well-watered everywhere, before Yahweh destroyed Sodom and Gomorrah, like the garden of Yahweh, like the land of Egypt, as you go to Zoar.

poem:
Like that offering,

	He consumed our sin

	And drank to the dregs

	That cursed cup of death

	So we could be cleansed,

	Delivered and born again.
versetext: The priest who offers it for sin shall eat it. It shall be eaten in a holy place, in the court of the Tent of Meeting.

poem:
Either caught up or captured down

	We all are going to disappear,

	Hidden by clouds or by ground.

	In the earth or in the air.
versetext: then we who are alive, who are left, will be caught up together with them in the clouds, to meet the Lord in the air. So we will be with the Lord forever.

poem:
His unselfish sacrifice

	Gave us eternal life.
versetext: who gave himself for us, that he might redeem us from all iniquity, and purify for himself a people for his own possession, zealous for good works.

poem:
Between earth and sky

	He was nailed to die.

	Entombed, yet after three days, out.

	Coming again, soon, with a secret shout!
versetext:
It was the third hour,
 and they crucified him.

poem:
Passover, pass over me and my family

	Like the roof above our home

	That bears the beatings from sun and storm,

	Shelter us from the terrors of night or day.

	Hide us from the accuser’s prying eyes.

	Make the destroyer pass over us and stay away,

	Never coming inside so that none within ever dies.

	Forever we will abide under Your love and grace

	That covers us in this place, and for all eternity.
versetext: Purge out the old yeast, that you may be a new lump, even as you are unleavened. For indeed Christ, our Passover, has been sacrificed in our place.

poem:
The tomb is not locked anymore.

	Hell and Death cannot keep us bound

	Because Jesus Christ descended down,

	Collected their keys to set us free,

	And risen, opened the doors.
versetext: and the Living one. I was dead, and behold, I am alive forever and ever. Amen. I have the keys of Death and of Hades.

poem:
Every time we take Communion

	We remember and show His crucifixion.

	But also, Jesus’ resurrection,

	And that He is coming back again.
versetext: For as often as you eat this bread and drink this cup, you proclaim the Lord’s death until he comes.

poem:
Some have their consciences seared as with fire,

	Like skin burnt and scarred by a red-hot iron.

	Others are as a team who refuse to hear the umpire.

	These dangerous last days will be filled with hypocritical liars

	And doctrines and ideas inspired by demons.
versetext: through the hypocrisy of men who speak lies, branded in their own conscience as with a hot iron;

poem:
I must humble myself and bow low.

	I fall to the earth facedown

	Where many feet have tread,

	Even some of who are now dead

	And returned to the ground,

	Unmoving and immobile below.

	Still more I humble myself, and go as low as I can.

	I repent again and again and again,

	Trusting You to raise me from here to the heights of heaven.
versetext: because your heart was tender, and you humbled yourself before God, when you heard his words against this place, and against its inhabitants, and have humbled yourself before me, and have torn your clothes, and wept before me, I also have heard you,” says Yahweh.

poem:
This evening, as you stand strong and upright

	Or lay awake staring up at the ceiling,

	Remember there are many past healing

	Who sleep outside under soil and sod

	With the rain or stars in their face,

	But they can’t leave their place.

	So get moving and doing something for God,

	Because you still have life and breath left tonight.
versetext: Therefore he says, “Awake, you who sleep, and arise from the dead, and Christ will shine on you.”

poem:
Lord of the Sabbath

	You are also Lord of Sabaoth.

	Oh Lord of Hosts,

	Fill us with Your Holy Ghost.

	Then we will win the war while we rest.
versetext:
As Isaiah has said before,
“Unless the Lord of Armies had left us a seed,
we would have become like Sodom,
and would have been made like Gomorrah.”

poem:
Let’s live like we are young and innocent once again,

	When we had no name or reputation to pretend and defend.

	We recognized no sins, faults or failures in others.

	No matter what shape or color, we played as brothers.

	So in understanding be men.

	In evil, be as little children.
versetext: Brothers, don’t be children in thoughts, yet in malice be babies, but in thoughts be mature.

poem:
Suppose all your lusts and desires were instantly gratified,

	Like that surfeit of quail that ran out of the mob’s noses.

	We would learn that being satiated here below never satisfies.

	That only happens above at His table and cup that overflows.
versetext:
He gave them their request,
but sent leanness into their soul.

poem:
There is no challenge in loving those with whom we agree

	Who are like us, and like us, and are in our family tree.

	Those different are easy to despise.

	But since to the same Savior and heaven we rise,

	Let us love and see all through our Father’s eyes.
versetext: Beloved, if God loved us in this way, we also ought to love one another.

poem:
Because these are the Last Days

We will see a great falling away.

	Sin and backsliding will increase

	And the faith of many decrease.

	Little Flock,

	Fear not.
versetext: Don’t be afraid, little flock, for it is your Father’s good pleasure to give you the Kingdom.

poem:
Upon Your finished work I rest.

	I know that there will be a test.

	But on Calvary’s cross all was done,

	So, through You, before I start, I’ve won.
versetext: For he who has entered into his rest has himself also rested from his works, as God did from his.

poem:
We trust You, and will not be shaken.

	When You return we will be taken.
versetext: Therefore, receiving a Kingdom that can’t be shaken, let us have grace, through which we serve God acceptably, with reverence and awe,

poem:
When you teach others,

	You learn more than they do.

	Like that scribe with the Scriptures

	You will bring out treasures

	From the Bible, both old and new.
versetext:
He said to them,
“Therefore every scribe who has been made a disciple in the Kingdom of Heaven is like a man who is a householder, who brings out of his treasure new and old things.”

poem:
Throughout my life I have been a wayfaring fool.

	I now bow face down in worship and reverence

	And fall in awe at Your feet

	Where heaven and earth meet,

	Where at Your heel the Devil met defeat.

	From now on I want to be Your resting place,

	A lowly, faithful and firm footstool.
versetext:
But which of the angels has he told at any time,
“Sit at my right hand,
until I make your enemies the footstool of your feet?”

poem:
You will be richer today

	If you give all away.
versetext:
When Jesus heard these things, he said to him,
“You still lack one thing. Sell all that you have, and distribute it to the poor. You will have treasure in heaven. Come, follow me.”

poem:
When it seems storms of sin will overwhelm us,

	And an avalanche of temptation descends too strong to resist

	Come shelter within Christ’s blood and wounds,

	And rest while the tempests and tremors flow past.
versetext:
A man shall be as a hiding place from the wind,
and a covert from the storm,
as streams of water in a dry place,
as the shade of a large rock in a weary land.

poem:
There is a tunnel through the skies and trees

	Going up through clouds or leaves.

	It makes this material world seem a funnel

	Through which we are taken up, whether we live or lay.

	It is near to wherever you are, or may go, or stay.

	Any moment you might go through it and leave

	To pour up to Him Who opened the way

	And is the life and light at the end of the tunnel.
versetext: in a moment, in the twinkling of an eye, at the last trumpet. For the trumpet will sound, and the dead will be raised incorruptible, and we will be changed.

poem:
This modern digital age is

	Flooded with tsunamis of webpages,

	And so many sites and channels to choose from.

	Yet all that data saves no one, and will be unsaved.

	It just fills up men’s time until they fill up their graves.
versetext: and those who use the world, as not using it to the fullest. For the mode of this world passes away.

poem:
As we continue to believe

	We continue to receive

	Brighter and brighter illumination

	And more and more revelation.

	Our path to perfect day becomes more clear

	Until we are caught up to a place where

	There is no need for sun or lamp there.
versetext:
But the path of the righteous is like the dawning light,
that shines more and more until the perfect day.

poem:
Some look forward to death as an escape to rest in peace,

	Thinking the grave is where all toils and sorrows cease.

	But it is only those who have already entered rest in this life

	That find eternal rest through faith in the finished work of Christ.
versetext: For we who have believed do enter into that rest, even as he has said, “As I swore in my wrath, they will not enter into my rest”; although the works were finished from the foundation of the world.

poem:
If God feels far away

	Realize that He did not move.

	Come back to your first love

	And stay.
versetext: But I have this against you, that you left your first love.

poem:
Oh Most Lofty, yet most humble,

	You are so, so, so high and holy.

	You inhabit eternity, still You dwell with the lowly.

	You bend and rise to deliver and conquer me.
versetext:
You have also given me the shield of your salvation.
Your right hand sustains me.
Your gentleness has made me great.

poem:
Each day in every way

	I put my old man and mind away.

	Let only and always,

	Only Your new man stay.
versetext: that you put away, as concerning your former way of life, the old man, that grows corrupt after the lusts of deceit;

poem:
The Devil will provide a way for us to escape the cross.

	If we take it, we become a stumbling and roadblock.

	Those generations following us would be lost,

	And our graves and Heaven’s entrance remain locked.
versetext:
He went forward a little, fell on his face, and prayed, saying,
“My Father, if it is possible, let this cup pass away from me; nevertheless, not what I desire, but what you desire.”

poem:
Instead of faces stuck in Facebook

	All will one day will have to face

	That inerasable hard drive,

The opened books of their lives,

Into which all in eternity will look

With no place, no space for us to hide.
versetext: I saw the dead, the great and the small, standing before the throne, and they opened books. Another book was opened, which is the book of life. The dead were judged out of the things which were written in the books, according to their works.

poem:
When we are gathered under His ensign

	From every tribe, tongue and nation,

	Every angel and all of creation

	Will see the risen Root of Jesse

	Resting in His glorious victory.
versetext: It will happen in that day that the nations will seek the root of Jesse, who stands as a banner of the peoples; and his resting place will be glorious.

poem:
God is light, but light is not Him.

	Yet even natural illumination

	Is beyond human comprehension.

	We can only know God by revelation.
versetext:
For with you is the spring of life.
In your light shall we see light.

poem:
In a garden that would soon become Jesus’ grave

	God heard His Beloved Son’s strong crying.

	There Jesus denied His own will, so we could be saved,

	And the Son was saved from spiritual death by dying.
versetext: He, in the days of his flesh, having offered up prayers and petitions with strong crying and tears to him who was able to save him from death, and having been heard for his godly fear,

poem:
In a way, you may need to die today.

	Because when people know their time is at an end

	They start to forsake all and give their treasures away,

	And say goodbye to enemy, family and friend.

	Not only this, they confess long hidden sin,

	And forgive everyone and ask all to be forgiven.

	So why not try to do this today while you are still living.
versetext: For he who has died has been freed from sin.

poem:
We will not give up or give in

	Until You establish Jerusalem

	Even then, we will keep going.

	And keep on worshiping.
versetext:
and give him no rest, until he establishes,
and until he makes Jerusalem a praise in the earth.

poem:
All men are born dead in sin

	Because that old man of Adam is living within.

	Even the new born babe and little children

	Will never truly live until they are born again
versetext: You were made alive when you were dead in transgressions and sins,

poem:
All of us can look up to the same constant constellations

	Made up of ever steady stars and their connections

	That give direction to those who follow their faithful courses.

	As all can look down into the same Chapters and Verses

	And read the unchanging lines with others, over all generations,

	Getting the same guidance to our eternal heavenly destination.
versetext:
Yahweh, who gives the sun for a light by day,
and the ordinances of the moon and of the stars for a light by night,
who stirs up the sea, so that its waves roar;
Yahweh of Armies is his name, says:

poem:
Let me worship without fear

	Even as in awe I fall down.

	May Your glorious splendor draw near

	And Your Holy flood and fire surround.
versetext:
Worship Yahweh in holy array.
Tremble before him, all the earth.

poem:
If you were given a death sentence this morning,

	Or be told you were terminal this evening,

	Would it be so important to know the latest sport score?

	Would wickets, runs, tries, and goals matter anymore?

	Would the latest DVD, movie, or TV series be so vital?

	Even the news and current events would no longer be crucial.

	Well, you have already been given an eternal life sentence,

	So why not start thinking more on your heavenly inheritance?
versetext: Set your mind on the things that are above, not on the things that are on the earth.

poem:
We will not give up or give in

	Until He establish Jerusalem,

	And not even then,

	Because we will be there with Him.
versetext:
and give him no rest, until he establishes,
and until he makes Jerusalem a praise in the earth.

poem:
We are a flock of lions

	Led by a Lamb.

	A pride of sheep

	Standing bold on Zion
versetext: One of the elders said to me, “Don’t weep. Behold, the Lion who is of the tribe of Judah, the Root of David, has overcome; he who opens the book and its seven seals.”

poem:
Seven eyes and seven horns,

	Perfect in power and wisdom.

	Wise to be silent when shorn,

	Power to rule from Zion.
versetext: I saw in the middle of the throne and of the four living creatures, and in the middle of the elders, a Lamb standing, as though it had been slain, having seven horns, and seven eyes, which are the seven Spirits of God, sent out into all the earth.

poem:
I am as a kid getting his first haircut

	Screaming for the shearing to stop

	Making things more painful and sharp.

	Not a meek lamb, but like a ram, I kick and butt.
versetext:
He was oppressed,
yet when he was afflicted he didn’t open his mouth.
As a lamb that is led to the slaughter,
and as a sheep that before its shearers is silent,
so he didn’t open his mouth.

poem:
Lord don’t stop for my sobbing or cease for my crying

	Make me smart enough to stay dumb under Your shears.

	I know when You hold the scissors, I am not dying.

	So as You finish, like falling fleece, sweep away my fears.
versetext:
Now the passage of the Scripture which he was reading was this,
“He was led as a sheep to the slaughter.
As a lamb before his shearer is silent,
so he doesn’t open his mouth.

poem:
Once I was given a haircut by a hypocrite.

	Because the unkempt barber who held the shears

	Himself had shaggy hair hanging over his ears.

	I cried to my father how unfair and unjust all this was.

	He told the clipper to keep cutting until I was quiet.

	As dad drove me home bald and bleeding, he taught this lesson,

	Son, don’t judge others, look in the mirror until the cutting is done.
versetext:
I gave my back to those who beat me,
and my cheeks to those who plucked off the hair.
I didn’t hide my face from shame and spitting.

poem:
Peter wasn’t aiming for an ear when he attacked,

	Wildly swinging his sword toward the head of Malchus.

	But the Lord meant it when He bent, picked it up and put it back.

	When we try to defend Jesus, He ends up saving others from us.
versetext: Simon Peter therefore, having a sword, drew it, and struck the high priest’s servant, and cut off his right ear. The servant’s name was Malchus.

poem:
We have eternal life

	It’s already given,

	So cease from strife

	And start living.
versetext: The testimony is this, that God gave to us eternal life, and this life is in his Son.

poem:
Let living waters keeping flowing and flowing

	From summer to winter and ocean to ocean.

	Even when we feel we can’t get going

	The spring of revival is always in motion.
versetext: It will happen in that day, that living waters will go out from Jerusalem; half of them toward the eastern sea, and half of them toward the western sea; in summer and in winter will it be.

poem:
Mary was the name of many of the women

	Who walked with, served and loved Jesus.

	Though now it sounds so sweet and is such a popular name.

	Its actual meaning and translation is ‘bitterness.’

	Throughout history females have borne not just the children

	But such an unequal amount of sorrow and pain.

	Yet as we find with the waters of Marah, and embittered Naomi,

	The sour becomes sweet though Calvary’s Tree.
versetext: Then he cried to Yahweh. Yahweh showed him a tree, and he threw it into the waters, and the waters were made sweet. There he made a statute and an ordinance for them, and there he tested them;

poem:
During His final night and meal

	The Lord wrapped Himself in a towel

	A foot rag, soon soaked and soiled

	From followers’ feet, that would shortly flee.

	But in eternity we see Him girdled in gold.

	It will be the same for you and me.

	Those we bear and care for down here

	Will be ornaments for us forever up there.
versetext: And among the lamp stands was one like a son of man, clothed with a robe reaching down to his feet, and with a golden sash around his chest.

poem:
A last act of Jesus at that last supper on that last night

	Was to wash His disciple’s scruffy feet.

	There may be a way for you to shine your light

	Other than from behind a mike and pulpit.

	How about kneeling behind a shoeshine kit?
versetext: Then he poured water into the basin, and began to wash the disciples’ feet, and to wipe them with the towel that was wrapped around him.

poem:
Don’t yield to your youthful lusts.

	If you are young, you better run

	Like Joseph did so long ago.

	Don’t debate. Just get out and go.
versetext: Flee sexual immorality! “Every sin that a man does is outside the body,” but he who commits sexual immorality sins against his own body.

poem:
Take the old me away

	Make me all new in every way

	And cause, ever and always,

	Only Your new man to stay.
versetext: Therefore if anyone is in Christ, he is a new creation. The old things have passed away. Behold, all things have become new.

poem:
Are you stuck to a World Wide Web,

	Ensnared in the Internet,

	Ever searching wherever led,

	Instead of at rest in your bed?
versetext:
For he is cast into a net by his own feet,
and he wanders into its mesh.

poem:
Are you bound in your house,

	Attached to a mouse

	But losing your home,

	Connected to billions, but sitting alone?

	Or are you out surfing and scrolling on a tablet?

	It is way past time for you to fast and diet,

	Not from food but your phone.
versetext:
“Isn’t this the fast that I have chosen:
to release the bonds of wickedness,
to undo the straps of the yoke,
to let the oppressed go free,
and that you break every yoke?

poem:
At Babel new tongues divided everyone

	But when Pentecost was fully come,

	And the disciples spoke in new tongues,

	It brought all the nations in Jerusalem

	Together to hear glorious things God had done.
versetext: When this sound was heard, the multitude came together, and were bewildered, because everyone heard them speaking in his own language.

poem:
One day your accusers may all be dead and gone

	With no one left to recall all the crimes you have done,

	No one alive to remember and condemn your wrongs.

	By default, in may appear that you have won.

	But with no enemies, you have no one to forgive,

	And above is a Witness and Judge that ever lives.
versetext:
“For his eyes are on the ways of a man.
He sees all his goings.

poem:
Be on your knees

	Unceasingly.
versetext: Pray without ceasing.

poem:
Men chasing wind as the sun circles humanity,

	Raising up towers, as they return to dust,

	Thinking their treasures will never rust.

	It is not in God that such idolaters trust

	But the futile objects of their own lust.

	Winning such riches impoverishes us,

	And always ends in vanity.
versetext:
“Vanity of vanities,” says the Preacher.
“All is vanity!”

poem:
When you are filled more and more with God’s Word

	You begin to lose sight of the things of this world.

	As we seek eternal things, the more we will see the unseen

	And then the temporary loses value and meaning.
versetext: while we don’t look at the things which are seen, but at the things which are not seen. For the things which are seen are temporal, but the things which are not seen are eternal.

poem:
Jesus ever lives to make intercession

	For us to become God’s perfected possession.
versetext: Therefore he is also able to save to the uttermost those who draw near to God through him, seeing that he lives forever to make intercession for them.

poem:
Satan tests to make us fail,

	The ones God gives teach us to prevail.
versetext:
Examine me, Yahweh, and prove me.
Try my heart and my mind.

poem:
The Devil sends trials to make us fall.

	God’s make us stand strong and tall.
versetext: Then Satan answered Yahweh, and said, “Does Job fear God for nothing?

poem:
We remember those who have gone before us

	And are now above as a cloud of witnesses.

	Many lives sacrificed had no medals awarded,

	But when Jesus returns they will be rewarded.
versetext: knowing that from the Lord you will receive the reward of the inheritance; for you serve the Lord Christ.

poem:
A tomb can be a dark closed door to doom

	But to the saved it is more like a womb.

	Asleep within the earth, in an instant they bloom

	When they hear the secret shout from the clouds on high,

	Suddenly the redeemed rise in their new bodies and fly.
versetext: For the Lord himself will descend from heaven with a shout, with the voice of the archangel, and with God’s trumpet. The dead in Christ will rise first,

poem:
In these last days men will create new sins and depravation.

	New chemical and electronic bondages and addictions,

	New genders invented along with their new perversions.

	These abominations should convict us and all creation to see

	The Judge of all flesh is just to send sudden fiery destruction.
versetext: But the heavens that now exist, and the earth, by the same word have been stored up for fire, being reserved against the day of judgment and destruction of ungodly men.

poem:
I thought the more I loved Jesus

	I would have to love men less.

	But it wasn’t like this,

	My love just became less selfish.
versetext: A second likewise is this, ‘You shall love your neighbor as yourself.’

poem:
Stay in today.

	Tomorrow is never here.

	Yesterday has gone away.

	Eternity is very near.
versetext: Therefore don’t be anxious for tomorrow, for tomorrow will be anxious for itself. Each day’s own evil is sufficient.

poem:
Lord I want You and Your word to live in me.

	I purpose to put on Your new man and mind.

	Let Your character replace mine.

	Then Your perfect image will shine,

	And Your nature will be all that others see.
versetext: and have put on the new man, who is being renewed in knowledge after the image of his Creator,

poem:
You may be weary working for your family

	Or have become tired laboring in the ministry

	But never get tired of ministering,

	Loving, serving, sharing, giving

	Because the blessed do it for all eternity.
versetext: There will be no curse any more. The throne of God and of the Lamb will be in it, and his servants will serve him.

poem:
Anyone, especially Satan, can make good into worse,

	But Jesus is the One that creates blessings from a curse.
versetext: Now the serpent was more subtle than any animal of the field which Yahweh God had made. He said to the woman, “Has God really said, ‘You shall not eat of any tree of the garden?’”

poem:
Once I felt the earth’s crust was like an eggshell

	Through which multitudes had fallen into Hell.

	Being saved I was safe, but not the burning souls who fell.

	Which reminded me of how close eternity is,

	And suddenly I felt an urgency to witness.
versetext:
The earth opened and swallowed up Dathan,
and covered the company of Abiram.

poem:
Once when I felt so low and of no worth,

	Physically and spiritually sick at the same time,

	I got a momentary vision of New Earth.

	Though it is the least and lowest place of heaven,

	Just that short glimpse made me smile and sing again

	And motivated me to get up, get out and get to witnessing.
versetext: But, according to his promise, we look for new heavens and a new earth, in which righteousness dwells.

poem:
When we bow our knees, we end up standing tall

	But those that stand against God, in the end will fall.

	In this life those who refuse and reject Him,

	With the rejected will be condemned.

	One day those who wouldn’t bow, will bend

	And all their tongues confess, Jesus wins.
versetext: that at the name of Jesus every knee should bow, of those in heaven, those on earth, and those under the earth,

poem:
If someone talks to themselves don’t always think them odd.

	It doesn’t always mean they have a split personality.

	Man too is a trinity.

	Your spirit may speak encouragement

	And your soul hear it.

	You can tell the soul to get up and worship.

	You soul can thank your body for its assistance

	In keeping you breathing, moving and serving God.
versetext:
Why are you in despair, my soul?
Why are you disturbed within me?
Hope in God!
For I shall still praise him:
my Savior, my helper, and my God.

poem:
When you begin to test your Maker

	It always ends in your failure.

	Let the Spirit give you a daily examination

	Until the final one at resurrection.
versetext: You shall not tempt Yahweh your God, as you tempted him in Massah.

poem:
Reign over me.

	I yield willingly,

	Even if it’s against my will.

	Let Your Kingdom come,

	And Thy will be done

	Help me surrender to be free.
versetext: Let your Kingdom come. Let your will be done, as in heaven, so on earth.

poem:
The one and only Holy Bible, ever new,

	That old story that never comes to an end,

	The only Book that we will never finish.

	But if we let it accomplish its purpose

	It will complete a perfect work in us

	Making us the Lamb’s wife, New Jerusalem.
versetext:
so is my word that goes out of my mouth:
it will not return to me void,
but it will accomplish that which I please,
and it will prosper in the thing I sent it to do.

poem:
When You visit us

	It becomes a holiday,

	Birthday and Christmas.
versetext:
Remember me, Yahweh, with the favor that you show to your people.
Visit me with your salvation,

poem:
Some treat the grace of God like grease

	And think they can slip and slide on it into heaven.

	Others live in folly, luxury and extravagance

	As if their Christian liberty was a sinner’s license.

	Many run first to doctors and medicine

	And never exercise faith, prayer or repentance,

	As if they will get to paradise in an ambulance.

	Grace works in us to make us work, not live in ease.
versetext: as free, and not using your freedom for a cloak of wickedness, but as bondservants of God.

poem:
The things good to you are often not good for you.

	The things that attract you often subtract from you.

	The people, places and things that charm often harm.

	The things that seem nice and entice often end in vice.
