versetext:
Don’t judge,
and you won’t be judged.
Don’t condemn,
and you won’t be condemned.
Set free,
and you will be set free.

poem:
Some are like bakers selling bread

	While leaving their families unfed.

	Or doctors that heal those that are ill

	But by neglect their own offspring kill.

	Don’t just give it,

	Live it!
versetext: Not everyone who says to me, ‘Lord, Lord,’ will enter into the Kingdom of Heaven; but he who does the will of my Father who is in heaven.

poem:
Listening for the Lord’s knock on your door

	Helps you get ready to rise and soar.

	Thinking the Lord will return at any instant

	Will help make and keep you ready for it.
versetext: For the Lord himself will descend from heaven with a shout, with the voice of the archangel, and with God’s trumpet. The dead in Christ will rise first,

poem:
When all is dark and silent

	He gives songs in the night.

	At times God will be your only delight,

	And He will be the only One to hear it.
versetext:
But no one says, ‘Where is God my Maker,
who gives songs in the night,

poem:
God gives His peace in the fear

	When shadows and threats are near.

	There are dark valleys you must pass through

	But His Ever-present Help is with you.
versetext:
Even though I walk through the valley of the shadow of death,
I will fear no evil, for you are with me.
Your rod and your staff,
they comfort me.

poem:
A subterranean river still flows

	Even if the eye of no man knows.

	A breeze no one breathes still blows.

	Grass sprouts even when no one sows,

	And the unseen evergreen still grows.

	Don’t think your life’s work is a feast untasted.

	With God as your witness nothing is ever wasted.
versetext: Oh the depth of the riches both of the wisdom and the knowledge of God! How unsearchable are his judgments, and his ways past tracing out!

poem:
There is music only you can make.

	There is art only you can create.

	The One and Only God made you an individual.

	Your soul and gift are unique and irreplaceable.
versetext: For the gifts and the calling of God are irrevocable.

poem:
Be as the trees.

	Reach up higher and higher like them,

	Always hungering for the light of heaven.

	Sing when the wind of the Spirit moves.

	Clap your hands for joy like their leaves,

	Limbs and branches do in the breeze.
versetext:
For you shall go out with joy,
and be led out with peace.
The mountains and the hills will break out before you into singing;
and all the trees of the fields will clap their hands.

poem:
Be as the Cedar of Lebanon, Palm and Olive

	Planted forever in God’s courts and house,

	Always digging deeper, rooted in His faith, hope and love.

	Drinking from hidden rivers of life and delight.

	Be evergreen, fruitful and flourishing in His light.
versetext:
The righteous shall flourish like the palm tree.
He will grow like a cedar in Lebanon.

poem:
Unseen growth,

	Rooted down,

	Before growth upward

	And fruit is found.
versetext: The remnant that has escaped of the house of Judah will again take root downward, and bear fruit upward.

poem:
Since most men no longer farm or work the soil

	They can’t appreciate the happiness of a harvest

	That comes after a long season of anticipation and toil.

	But we will soon be reaped and gathered up to our rest,

	When after years of tears and fears comes the Rapture

	And our sorrow is turned into rejoicing and laughter.
versetext:
He who goes out weeping, carrying seed for sowing,
will certainly come again with joy, carrying his sheaves.

poem:
A slain and risen lamb stands on Zion

	With a multitude in the midst of the mountain,

	And also at its summit and foundation,

	A Stone cut without hands, breaking others down,

	And filling all the earth with His Kingdom.
versetext: Then the iron, the clay, the brass, the silver, and the gold were broken in pieces together, and became like the chaff of the summer threshing floors. The wind carried them away, so that no place was found for them. The stone that struck the image became a great mountain, and filled the whole earth.

poem:
Just because Jehovah is so high

	Doesn’t mean you shouldn’t try

	To draw near Him.

	Just because Jesus is so lowly and meek

	Doesn’t mean you shouldn’t seek

	To hide beside Him.
versetext:
For though Yahweh is high, yet he looks after the lowly;
but the proud, he knows from afar.

poem:
Lord You are the living stone

	Rejected now by men,

	Only recognized by revelation.

	Like Peter, I return to You again.
versetext: coming to him, a living stone, rejected indeed by men, but chosen by God, precious.

poem:
A pristine, polished Bible on the table

	Reminds me of a feast uneaten.

	So sit down and with both hands dig in.

	The more you eat, the more you will be able.
versetext:
Your words were found,
and I ate them.
Your words were to me a joy and the rejoicing of my heart,
for I am called by your name, Yahweh, God of Armies.

poem:
From every good thing Satan makes evil come.

	God takes bad and makes good through His son.
versetext: Since then the children have shared in flesh and blood, he also himself in the same way partook of the same, that through death he might bring to nothing him who had the power of death, that is, the devil,

poem:
Oh, Most Holy One

	Ruler of all,

	To You I call.

	Thy will be done!
versetext: Let your Kingdom come. Let your will be done, as in heaven, so on earth.

poem:
Lord,

	Every day,

	In every way,

	We will worship and adore.
versetext:
In God we have made our boast all day long,
we will give thanks to your name forever.
Selah.

poem:
Living God, loving Lord Jesus,

	By Your Holy Spirit inspire us

	To lift to You our hands, our hearts, our all.

	And at the same time bow face down in awe.
versetext:
Be exalted, God, above the heavens!
Let your glory be above all the earth!

poem:
Before the temple in Jerusalem stood two pillars of brass

	Which were even given names, Jachin and Boaz.

	They were two strong and silent witnesses

	Testifying ‘In Him is Strength’ and ‘He Establishes.’
versetext: He set up the pillars at the porch of the temple. He set up the right pillar, and called its name Jachin; and he set up the left pillar, and called its name Boaz.

poem:
Those two pillars carried no weight, nor bore any roof,

	But were solid, steadfast, and visible proof

	That when manifold sufferings surround

	His supporting grace will never let us down,

	And even if encompassed by multitudes of enemies,

	By the unseen God’s strength, we will stand in victory.
versetext: But may the God of all grace, who called you to his eternal glory by Christ Jesus, after you have suffered a little while, perfect, establish, strengthen, and settle you.

poem:
We can all be immersed together

	In the Spirits living river,

	While as individuals we can imbibe

	From that same stream of life.
versetext: For in one Spirit we were all baptized into one body, whether Jews or Greeks, whether bond or free; and were all given to drink into one Spirit.

poem:
Holy Spirit, envelop and indwell,

	Like a flood and a well,

	Wind breathe upon us and within,

	Be fire surrounding and empowering,

	And oil anointing and absorbed,

	Baptize and fill us Lord!
versetext: I indeed baptize you in water for repentance, but he who comes after me is mightier than I, whose shoes I am not worthy to carry. He will baptize you in the Holy Spirit.

poem:
To adults cynical and jaded

	Nothing is scared

	And innocence is overrated.

	Yet Jesus tells us to be converted

	With hearts becoming like little children

	If we want to enter His Kingdom of Heaven.
versetext:
and said,
“Most certainly I tell you, unless you turn, and become as little children, you will in no way enter into the Kingdom of Heaven.

poem:
Don’t worry about your reputation

	Or the public’s perception.

	Only God sees the true you

	And knows you better that you do.

	In fact, you are actually so wicked and bad inside,

	It is something from you that God must hide.
versetext:
The heart is deceitful above all things
and it is exceedingly corrupt.
Who can know it?

poem:
There is a certain kind of tyranny

	In the New Testament Pharisee

	With their super-spirituality

	And self-proclaimed authority.

	Since they have all the answers for being perfected

	There is no way they will listen or be corrected.

	They refuse to see their religion is a form of idolatry.
versetext: You blind Pharisee, first clean the inside of the cup and of the platter, that its outside may become clean also.

poem:
Rejoice!

	It not hard to say again,

	Rejoice again.

	Keep going.

	Never let it end!
versetext: Rejoice in the Lord always! Again I will say, “Rejoice!”

poem:
You have only a certain number of days

	But no limit to your worship and praise.
versetext:
So teach us to count our days,
that we may gain a heart of wisdom.

poem:
So many fallen generations and forgotten nations

	Have returned and turned to dust,

	Just as any future ones must.

 	Facing such futility and vanity all is lost

	Without the triumph of the Cross and Resurrection
versetext:
Man is like a breath.
His days are like a shadow that passes away.

poem:
Many of the nouns you lust for

	Won’t matter anymore

	Once you’ve got them,

	You’ll just thirst for more.
versetext: The world is passing away with its lusts, but he who does God’s will remains forever.

poem:
God is terrible, in a wonderful way.

	His Magnificent Majesty

	Is so high above all we can see or say.

	We tremble and fall in awe at His glory.
versetext:
For Yahweh Most High is awesome.
He is a great King over all the earth.

poem:
Imagine there’s no heaven

	It’s easy if you lie

	No hell below us

	As the dammed deny.

	Imagine all the deceived

	Dying in their sin.

	I hope you will never join them

	And that you become Born Again.
versetext:
The fool has said in his heart, “There is no God.”
They are corrupt.
They have done abominable deeds.
There is no one who does good.

poem:
Perhaps you don’t want to give up your life.

	It only natural you should feel this way.

	Until today that attitude has helped you to survive.

	But since we all are leaving this earth anyway

	Why not say no to you and give your life to God willingly?

	Take up your cross and do what the Lord tells you to.

	There is something supernatural waiting for you.
versetext:
He called the multitude to himself with his disciples, and said to them,
“Whoever wants to come after me, let him deny himself, and take up his cross, and follow me.

poem:
It used to be in the West that the greatest sin was racism

	Which is hating someone for their culture, custom or skin.

	Now the greatest cultural crime is to hate a sin

	That God and nature finds an abomination,

	Which is the perverse and abhorrent Sin of Sodom
versetext: Likewise also the men, leaving the natural function of the woman, burned in their lust toward one another, men doing what is inappropriate with men, and receiving in themselves the due penalty of their error.

poem:
You may not be a mighty Christian superhero

	With a megachurch, mega smile and anointed preaching,

	And don’t have a gift of deliverance or divine healing.

	As a Christian musician your top ten hits are less than zero.

	You have no program on the net, TV or radio.

	By modern standards of measuring popularity and fame

	You have no value, and nobody knows your name.

	Stop judging yourself by worldly standards of success,

	And know in Jesus Christ you are precious and blessed.
versetext: The beggar died, and he was carried away by the angels to Abraham’s bosom. The rich man also died, and was buried.

poem:
All those terrible warnings and woes

	Pronounced by the Prophets so long ago

	Over rebellious men and nations

	Were given over and over before anything was done.

	Often it looked like the enemy had won

	And God’s punishment would never come.

	In our current time of complacency and security

	It’s all just an old story and ancient history.

	Once again men scoff, forget or are willingly ignorant

	That the next one to come is the Last Judgement.
versetext: For this they willfully forget, that there were heavens from of old, and an earth formed out of water and amid water, by the word of God;

poem:
Wake up, get up, in whatever zone or clime.

	Christ has been shining all this time.

	Rise up from your bed

	And stop being spiritually dead.
versetext: Therefore he says, “Awake, you who sleep, and arise from the dead, and Christ will shine on you.”

poem:
Shake off your lethargy

	Receive resurrection energy.

	It is never too late or early

	To awaken to righteousness.

	Leap up, get dressed and be blessed.
versetext: Do this, knowing the time, that it is already time for you to awaken out of sleep, for salvation is now nearer to us than when we first believed.

poem:
In returning and rest

	We would have been blest

	But we say we will not stay,

	On our swift horses we will race away.

	So off on our own thoughts and plans we flee

	To end up losing all control and liberty.
versetext: For thus said the Lord Yahweh, the Holy One of Israel, “You will be saved in returning and rest. Your strength will be in quietness and in confidence.” You refused,

poem:
The times when I consider myself the more wise

	I question, “why don’t they do things differently?”

	So I’m tempted to overrule those that rule over me.

	But then the Lord of lords helps me to realize

	That so far, I haven’t even controlled me.
versetext: Obey your leaders and submit to them, for they watch on behalf of your souls, as those who will give account, that they may do this with joy, and not with groaning, for that would be unprofitable for you.

poem:
When we rebel and do wrong continually

	We become accustomed to sin and failure.

	Because of our own stubborn behavior,

	Disobedient acts and defiance become familiar

	And eventually those habits become our character.

	Let the Beloved and obedient Son break your captivity.
versetext: Then the lust, when it has conceived, bears sin; and the sin, when it is full grown, produces death.

poem:
Right now, towering over you and me

	And all of history, and eternity

	Is His awesome and glorious majesty

	That one day all will bow before and see.

	We have the privilege to do it presently.
versetext: Therefore God also highly exalted him, and gave to him the name which is above every name;

poem:
When the adversary repeats your past

	And all your former sins,

	Remember he cannot win.

	His accusations will not last.

	Then you can remind that liar

	His future is fixed and certain

	After he falls for a Millennium,

	Then forever in the Lake of Fire.
versetext: The devil who deceived them was thrown into the lake of fire and sulfur, where the beast and the false prophet are also. They will be tormented day and night forever and ever.

poem:
There once was a madman named of ham and mud

	Who made a religion of peace which was really of blood

	With martyrs who murdered and thought they did well

	But woke to meet their false prophet, not in heaven, but hell.
versetext: All who came before me are thieves and robbers, but the sheep didn’t listen to them.

poem:
Once while I was weeping in my private Gethsemane

	I sensed the presence of angels’ wings or’shadowing me,

	And thought God alone knows my great agony,

	Heaven is showing me some sympathy!

	But it was only a big bird bombing me.

	Then laughing, I learned to get over me,

	And stop taking my own misery so seriously.
versetext:
I chattered like a swallow or a crane.
I moaned like a dove.
My eyes weaken looking upward.
Lord, I am oppressed.
Be my security.”

poem:
Preserve your heritage

	Treasure your inheritance

	Don’t trade it for a pot or hill of beans

	Keep your birthright, it can’t be replaced by anything.
versetext: lest there be any sexually immoral person, or profane person, like Esau, who sold his birthright for one meal.

poem:
Don’t devalue the currency of your testimony

	You can’t buy it back so cheaply or easily.
versetext: For you know that even when he afterward desired to inherit the blessing, he was rejected, for he found no place for a change of mind though he sought it diligently with tears.

poem:
I wrote this silent song

	Instead of sang it.

	Let someone come along

	And add the music.
versetext: For in this the saying is true, ‘One sows, and another reaps.’

poem:
Send Your Word to save and heal.

	Send Your Holy Spirit to seal.

	Send Your servants to make it real,

	And unsearchable riches reveal.
versetext: To me, the very least of all saints, was this grace given, to preach to the Gentiles the unsearchable riches of Christ,

poem:
Certain musicians seeing the audience not moving

	Add more instruments and crank up the volume.

	Some pastors when they see their flock is doubting

	Purchase bigger speakers and do more shouting.
versetext: They took the bull which was given them, and they dressed it, and called on the name of Baal from morning even until noon, saying, “Baal, hear us!” But there was no voice, and nobody answered. They leaped about the altar which was made.

poem:
Some preachers see their listeners bored and snoring

	So they start jumping, pounding and roaring.

	But like hope and love, faith is sometimes quiet.

	So next time nothing is working, try it.
versetext: If I speak with the languages of men and of angels, but don’t have love, I have become sounding brass, or a clanging cymbal.

poem:
Next time you feel a meeting will never end

	Think poor tired Eutychus and his friends.

	Paul droned on so long he fell asleep and dead,

	Only to have Paul raise him up again,

	Then keep on preaching until morning.
versetext: A certain young man named Eutychus sat in the window, weighed down with deep sleep. As Paul spoke still longer, being weighed down by his sleep, he fell down from the third floor, and was taken up dead.

poem:
Even if your wounds are self-inflicted

	They still hurt, and leave scars, but no reward.

	So save yourself from being uselessly afflicted

	And let the Lord wield the sword.
versetext: For what glory is it if, when you sin, you patiently endure beating? But if, when you do well, you patiently endure suffering, this is commendable with God.

poem:
Satan get out and go away.

	In Jesus’ Name, run!

	By the power of God’s Son

	You are not allowed to stay.
versetext: These signs will accompany those who believe: in my name they will cast out demons; they will speak with new languages;

poem:
You may get glimpses of souls as you speed down a highway,

	When crowded and crushed by them on a sidewalk or subway,

	Or imagining their lives in the homes below as you fly by.

	Their burdens are too many and heavy. What can one person do?

	There are lots and lots of them and so little of you.

	But as you hurry through the press and hasten past

	With the help of the Helper at least you can broadcast

	A prayer for their salvation, healing and deliverance.

	There’s no knowing below the fruits of the hurried blessings you sow.

	Only in heaven will we see how those scattered seeds did grow.

There once was a woman from Bethany

	Who would try to hide herself from God

	In busy work and odd jobs.

	No one could ever dare disagree

	That she did her duties diligently.

	Yet not all of them were necessary,

	Except as an escape from eternity.
versetext:
Jesus answered her,
“Martha, Martha, you are anxious and troubled about many things,

poem:
Water in stone pots transformed into wine,

Nets filled, fish and bread multiplied,

The healing and deliverance of multitudes,

All these took place in the hands of disciples.

Jesus made all this happen as signs

Of Who He is, and how He can use you,

If you just obey and do what He tells you to.
versetext: Simon answered him, “Master, we worked all night, and took nothing; but at your word I will let down the net.”

poem:
Do you ever feel you never fulfil your full potential?

	Some reasons are lethargy and laziness,

	But others are fear of failure and fear of success.

	Thinking the more you do, the more you will be capable,

	Then more and more will be required, so you just stay still.

	Only in Heaven will we achieve all that can possibly be done,

	Yet still our Master commands us to occupy until He comes.
versetext:
He called ten servants of his, and gave them ten mina coins,

and told them, ‘Conduct business until I come.’

poem:
When the Lord leads

	Moment by moment, day by day

	He meets all needs

	And will make a way.
versetext:
Yahweh,
your Redeemer,
the Holy One of Israel says:
“I am Yahweh your God,
who teaches you to profit,
who leads you by the way that you should go.

poem:
‘The gates of Hell shall not prevail’

	Does not mean the church is hiding behind them,

	But that it is storming Satan’s citadel,

	Breaking down his fortress, and spoiling him.
versetext:
I also tell you that you are Peter,
and on this rock

I will build my assembly, and the gates of Hades
will not prevail against it.

poem:
Him I trust

	Not because I must

	But because I want to.

	He alone is totally true.
versetext: Preserve me, God, for in you do I take refuge.

poem:
I am like an evergreen olive tree

	Strong, fruitful and flourishing

	Planted where none is supposed to be seen.

	Yet in His house I will abide eternally.
versetext:
But as for me, I am like a green olive tree in God’s house.
I trust in God’s loving kindness forever and ever.

poem:
It is so sad to see those whose current destiny

	Is to end in eternal death and destruction

	More worried about issues that end in vanity

	Like Global Warming and fighting pollution.

	Such activism and zeal are admirable

	Saving the planet is a very noble goal,

	But not at the cost of neglecting one’s soul.
versetext: For what does it profit a man, to gain the whole world, and forfeit his life?

poem:
His rest is glorious

	His choice the best.

	So we look to Him,

	Our Ensign who is risen

	And returning victorious.
versetext: It will happen in that day that the nations will seek the root of Jesse, who stands as a banner of the peoples; and his resting place will be glorious.

poem:
On a forgotten foreign battlefield

	I saw many well-ordered headstones,

	Cratered meadows that harvest still yielded

	To fill mausoleums stacked with unknown bones.

	With the evidence before me of the deaths of so many

	Who gave or lost all for their earthly country

	I thought, why don’t I do it for the heavenly?
versetext: By this we know love, because he laid down his life for us. And we ought to lay down our lives for the brothers.

poem:
Like Sons of Abraham, we are pilgrims.

	We don’t know for how long or how far

	But we hope our sojourn below will soon be done

	And we leave sons of sand to join the ones of stars.
versetext: Therefore as many as the stars of the sky in multitude, and as innumerable as the sand which is by the sea shore, were fathered by one man, and him as good as dead.

poem:
He found us in our low estate,

	In a blasted and darkened desert.

	Yet we were to the Most High

	As the apple of His eye,

	Protected and precious.
versetext:
He found him in a desert land,
in the waste howling wilderness.
He surrounded him.
He cared for him.
He kept him as the apple of his eye.

poem:
As long as I shall live

	Praise to God I will give,

	And if I die and fly

	I will do it even more on high.
versetext:
I will sing to Yahweh as long as I live.
I will sing praise to my God while I have any being.

poem:
Are spiritual offspring missing?

	Maybe you have stopped bearing

	Because you are no longer sharing.

	Get witnessing.
versetext: Again, “I will put my trust in him.” Again, “Behold, here I am with the children whom God has given me.”

poem:
Yes, flowers do fade and decay into dust,

	And every durable thing will melt and rust,

	Nevertheless, use each bit of beauty you experience,

	Even though it ends in loss and death,

	To give praise to God with each brief breath.
versetext:
Let everything that has breath praise Yah!
Praise Yah!

poem:
Light is sweet to see

	And so is the sun.

	Life is precious,

	We only get one.

	But His lovingkindness

	Is better utterly,

	And ever was,

	And ever will be.
versetext:
Truly the light is sweet,
and a pleasant thing it is for the eyes to see the sun.

poem:
Signs of Sodom whose end will come again:

	First, the first sin, pride like Satan.

	So overfed and fat while they let the starving diet,

	Abundant entertainment and leisure,

	Fulltime surrender to lust and pleasure.

	Then in the end, homosexual abomination.

	Doesn’t this sound like developed nations,

	And this final generation?
versetext: “‘“Behold, this was the iniquity of your sister Sodom: pride, fullness of bread, and prosperous ease was in her and in her daughters. She also didn’t strengthen the hand of the poor and needy.

poem:
Signs of the last days:

	Saving whales and trees, but murder unborn babies.

	Fearing global warming but not Hell they are headed for.

	Disobedient children to whom parents surrender.

	Abasing themselves lower than beasts, that at least know their gender.

	When these signs of the time take place

	It marks the end of the period of grace.
versetext: But know this, that in the last days, grievous times will come.

poem:
Collecting, keeping, hoarding and heaping possessions

	Can become an endless obsession.

	Ceaseless chasing of bargains and good deals

	Will hinder you from riches that are real.
versetext: So is he who lays up treasure for himself, and is not rich toward God.”

poem:
Many give thanks before they eat,

	Not many after they leave their seat.

	Most will pray and plead

	When hungry or in need

	But when fat and fit,

	They forget to do it.
versetext: You shall eat and be full, and you shall bless Yahweh your God for the good land which he has given you.

poem:
It isn’t when we are hungry and thirsty

	But when all is going good and easy

	That we neglect thankfulness

	And lose our gratefulness.

	Therefore, after you have everything you need

	Keep an attitude of gratitude for all you received.
versetext: Beware lest you forget Yahweh your God, in not keeping his commandments, and his ordinances, and his statutes, which I command you today;

poem:
God ever lives,

	As do you though Jesus.

	You are His.

	Thanks ever give!
versetext: Yet the number of the children of Israel will be as the sand of the sea, which can’t be measured or counted; and it will come to pass that, in the place where it was said to them, ‘You are not my people,’ they will be called ‘sons of the living God.’

poem:
You have enemies and valleys to go through.

	Goodness and mercy will follow you.

	They do not always go ahead.

	That was done by the Good Shepherd.
versetext:
Surely goodness and loving kindness shall follow me all the days of my life,
and I will dwell in Yahweh’s house forever.

poem:
So many are seeking for psychics and supermen

	With magic and superpowers at their command.

	Adults are following fantasies not fit for children

	With witches and mutants as their champions.

	But the real hero came down from heaven

	Leaving His powers behind to live as a lowly mortal man.

	He defeated sin, death and Satan when He rose again.
versetext: but emptied himself, taking the form of a servant, being made in the likeness of men.

poem:
Many want to be idols, stars and all the rage,

	And play the leading part in history.

	But before time began, that role was His Story.

 	So stop all the drama and give Jesus the stage.
versetext: He is the head of the body, the assembly, who is the beginning, the firstborn from the dead; that in all things he might have the preeminence.

poem:
Men don’t need to look without for treasure,

	Fortune, wealth and lasting pleasure.

	They need not mine or dive for riches,

	Nor chase rainbows, Lotos, cards or horses.

	Only in Jesus is lasting and true value hidden.

	When we find Christ and His Kingdom within we win.
versetext: to whom God was pleased to make known what are the riches of the glory of this mystery among the Gentiles, which is Christ in you, the hope of glory;

poem:
When you see a sunrise, thank God for your eyes.

	When you see a sunset, thank God who created it.
versetext:
From the rising of the sun to the going down of the same,
Yahweh’s name is to be praised.

poem:
When after a storm you see a rainbow

	Thank God, that for you, His anger was slow.
versetext: I set my rainbow in the cloud, and it will be a sign of a covenant between me and the earth.

poem:
Whenever you see gathering cloud,

	Listen for His voice to shout out loud.
versetext: Behold, he is coming with the clouds, and every eye will see him, including those who pierced him. All the tribes of the earth will mourn over him. Even so, Amen.

poem:
Underneath, His everlasting, almighty arms.

	Over, His infinite wings protecting from harm.

	Illuminating whirlwind at night turns to sheltering cloud by day.

	He defends before, behind, through all time and in all our way.
versetext:
The eternal God is your dwelling place.
Underneath are the everlasting arms.
He thrust out the enemy from before you,
and said, ‘Destroy!’

poem:
The joy set before Him

	Wasn’t just to see the Bride

	But to sit together again

	At His Father’s side.
versetext: looking to Jesus, the author and perfecter of faith, who for the joy that was set before him endured the cross, despising its shame, and has sat down at the right hand of the throne of God.

poem:
“Awake thou that sleepest, and arise from the dead,”

	Not one of my favorite Scripture quotations.

	Let the sunrise wait, I plead prone on my bed.

	The Old Man kept me up too late to function.

	But the New Man wants revival and resurrection.

	By which one of them should I be led?
versetext: Therefore he says, “Awake, you who sleep, and arise from the dead, and Christ will shine on you.”

poem:
Extra days means extra praise

	For the Ancient of Days.

	Therefore, the longer you live

	The more of it you can give.

	If you survive a little more,

	Use it to serve Him and adore.
versetext:
While I live, I will praise Yahweh.
I will sing praises to my God as long as I exist.

poem:
We are called to know Him Who passes knowing,

	And make the Infinite, Eternal, Unknowable known.

	To discover and describe the indescribable,

	Comprehend Him who is without measure,

	Apprehend Him Who has already captured us,

	Be filled with the infinite fullness

	Of Him Who fills all and overflows.
versetext: and to know Christ’s love which surpasses knowledge, that you may be filled with all the fullness of God.

poem:
Shepherd of our soul

	Enfold and hold

	Us in Your fold.
versetext:
I have other sheep, which are not of this fold.
I must bring them also, and they will hear my voice. They will become one flock with one shepherd.

poem:
What do you have that you did not receive?

	All that is not from above, you will have to leave.
versetext: For who makes you different? And what do you have that you didn’t receive? But if you did receive it, why do you boast as if you had not received it?

poem:
Take the rest of my time.

	Rule over the little I have left.

	I can only claim today as mine

	And return it to You to be blest.
versetext: Therefore don’t be anxious for tomorrow, for tomorrow will be anxious for itself. Each day’s own evil is sufficient.

poem:
When Jesus Christ is in control of us, time isn’t.

	He caused the lengthening shadows to retreat,

	And for an entire day made the sun to stand.

	Now and forever, our times are in His Hand.
versetext:
My times are in your hand.
Deliver me from the hand of my enemies, and from those who persecute me.

poem:
If you find out late that your life has been a waste,

	In one day God can restore and reinstate what you lost.

	If the brief time you have left seems too short,

	In one day He can do a thousand years of work.

	You are not limited or defined by years before and behind.

	Let Jesus be Lord, not just of your heart, but also of your time.
versetext:
I will restore to you the years that the swarming locust has eaten,
the great locust, the grasshopper, and the caterpillar,
my great army, which I sent among you.

poem:
Today one can hear so many popular Christian artists

	Judging those they say are judgmental and legalistic.

	They make sinners to be martyrs of their hypothetical hypocrites,

	While they call good evil and change light for darkness.

	As they condemn God’s messengers of holiness

	They promise their misled listeners freedom and liberty,

	While they themselves are in bondage and captivity.

Bless us. Keep us. Give grace.

	Shine down on us Your uplifted face.

	Put Your Name on us, and give peace.
versetext:
Yahweh make his face to shine on you,
and be gracious to you.

poem:
We know not the way of the Spirit,

	Where and How He works in secret,

	But when He moves we hear it,

	Like the breeze in the trees

	That blows where it pleases.

	Like the unborn baby in the womb,

	And sleeping saints in their tomb

	When God is finished we will see it.
versetext:
My frame wasn’t hidden from you,
when I was made in secret,
woven together in the depths of the earth.

poem:
Eager expectation, hopeful anticipation;

	Thinking that Jesus is near

	Will prepare you to hear

	And meet Him in the air.

	You will be ready for resurrection

	Even if it’s not for another millennium.
versetext: Little children, these are the end times, and as you heard that the Antichrist is coming, even now many antichrists have arisen. By this we know that it is the final hour.

poem:
God ever lives,

	And so shall we,

	To worship eternally

	And all praise give.
versetext:
I will exalt you, my God, the King.
I will praise your name forever and ever.

poem:
So many injuries and tragedies could have come,

	So much damage to you could have been done,

	Yet you are still here in the land of the living

	And not already buried in the earth sleeping.

	God and His angels have kept you in all your way

	And they will watch and keep you until the final day.
versetext:
For he will put his angels in charge of you,
to guard you in all your ways.

poem:
After your death will this world consider you a success

	If you leave no monuments, buildings or businesses?

	Will your life have mattered if in the media you leave no memory,

	And your entire existence becomes a mystery to history?

	The answer is No, from those who live only for fallen humanity.

	But for us who look to the risen Savior, the answer is, Yes,

	According to His promise to us, “Thou shalt not be forgotten of me.”
versetext:
Remember these things, Jacob and Israel;
for you are my servant.
I have formed you.
You are my servant.
Israel, you will not be forgotten by me.

poem:
From the sunrise until its going down,

	From the start of the year to its end,

	From our birth until resurrection,

	God is our ever-present help and friend.
versetext:
From the rising of the sun to the going down of the same,
Yahweh’s name is to be praised.

poem:
God is leading you wherever you travel.

	Though some of the rocky roads He takes you on

	Make you feel you are chewing and sucking on gravel.

	You will learn that even from the sharpest stone,

	Something sweet and healing will come.
versetext:
He made him ride on the high places of the earth.
He ate the increase of the field.
He caused him to suck honey out of the rock,
oil out of the flinty rock;

poem:
If you knew you were losing your life today

	Would you suddenly start giving everything away?

	If by this evening you were not going to be alive

	Would you start the day emptying your closet and hard drive?
versetext: “But God said to him, ‘You foolish one, tonight your soul is required of you. The things which you have prepared—whose will they be?’

poem:
So many temporal things you hoard and hold

	Are weighing down your immortal soul.

	So why not start lightening your load

	And unpack your bags before you go.
versetext: For we brought nothing into the world, and we certainly can’t carry anything out.

poem:
The promise is to us and our children

	And to all that were afar.

	When that verse was written

	We the ones not there.

	But now we can proclaim the same

	For the following generations.
versetext: For the promise is to you, and to your children, and to all who are far off, even as many as the Lord our God will call to himself.”

poem:
Who first recognized and responded to the presence of Jesus?

	A young virgin who surrendered to God’s will being done,

	A baby in the womb rejoicing in his Lord before both were born,

	An ancient aunt who had for so many years been barren,

	A senior citizen ready to depart in peace named Simeon,

	Anna, an aged and long widowed centenarian.

	All those who society aborts, rejects and neglects

	Still have worth and work to do as witnesses.
versetext: for my eyes have seen your salvation,

poem:
In the Bible birthday parties turned out bad.

	From both of them someone lost their head.

	And the expensive gifts given by the wise men

	After they first went to the wrong town by their wisdom

	Led to the deaths of the innocents in Bethlehem.
versetext:
“A voice was heard in Ramah,
lamentation, weeping and great mourning,
Rachel weeping for her children;
she wouldn’t be comforted,
because they are no more.”

poem:
Emmanuel, when You are with us all is well.

	You know from where You come, and where You go.

	At times we see You small, yet You are always in control,

	And the government is upon Your shoulder
versetext: Therefore the Lord himself will give you a sign. Behold, the virgin will conceive, and bear a son, and shall call his name Immanuel.

poem:
You will not die but live.

	You still have more praise to give.

	You still have a testimony share.

	You still have more fruit to bear.
versetext:
I will not die, but live,
and declare Yah’s works.

poem:
No matter what has happened here

	You will be satisfied forever there.

	Healthy and always happy in heaven,

	Joyful with strength that never ends.
versetext: Most certainly I tell you, that you will weep and lament, but the world will rejoice. You will be sorrowful, but your sorrow will be turned into joy.

poem:
Jesus is taking us for a ride to the other side

	But our fears see the wind and waves, time and tide.

	As we sink our unseen Master seems to hide.

	Yet He is still in the boat and it is still afloat.

	Even if sometimes Jesus seems silent and asleep,

	His promises and passengers He will keep.
versetext:
On that day, when evening had come, he said to them,
“Let’s go over to the other side.”

poem:
God is going to bring you to an expected end

	A sheltered harbor and desired destination.

	He alone knows all the thoughts for you He thinks

	And you will make it, you are not going to sink.
versetext: For I know the thoughts that I think toward you,” says Yahweh, “thoughts of peace, and not of evil, to give you hope and a future.

poem:
Jesus may return this day or year.

	But if not for another Century

	Do you have that much time to escape the cemetery?

	Whenever it is, soon we will meet Him together in the air!
versetext:
He who testifies these things says,
“Yes, I come quickly.”

Amen! Yes, come, Lord Jesus.

poem:
Often what the God showed you in the beginning

	He will accomplish and fulfill at the ending.

	The same kind of river, tree, garden,

	Goodly pearls and gold seen in Eden

	Will be fully revealed and realized in New Jerusalem.

	That very last, very good thing made, a beautiful bride,

	All will see as the Lamb’s Wife, forever at His side.
versetext: in the middle of its street. On this side of the river and on that was the tree of life, bearing twelve kinds of fruits, yielding its fruit every month. The leaves of the tree were for the healing of the nations.
